IRS990.ActivityOrMissionDescription: Muhlenberg aims to help students become independent critical thinkers who are intellectually agile, characterized by a zest for reasoned and civil debate, knowledgeable about the achievements and traditions of diverse civilizations and cultures, able to express ideas with clarity and grace, committed to life-long learning, equipped with ethical and civic values and prepared for lives of leadership and service.
IRS990.MissionDescription: Muhlenberg aims to help students become independent critical thinkers who are intellectually agile, characterized by a zest for reasoned and civil debate, knowledgeable about the achievements and traditions of diverse civilizations and cultures, able to express ideas with clarity and grace, committed to life-long learning, equipped with ethical and civic values and prepared for lives of leadership and service.
IRS990.Description: Instruction and research expenditures for approximately 2,193 full-time undergraduate students. The College offers 40 majors in the humanities, fine arts, social sciences and natural sciences, in addition to strong pre-professional programs in such areas as pre-health, pre-law, pre-theology, business and education. Muhlenberg professors are experts in their fields. They conduct cutting-edge research, publish books and papers, are quoted in the media, present at conferences, and win awards. Muhlenberg professors are the force behind the College's unmatched connectivity. They drive the rich and rewarding curriculum, which connects and combines classical liberal arts with outstanding pre-professional study.

Activity2.Description: Other program services: Library, depreciation, interest, non-cash financial aid, amortization of bond settlement costs (2,193 ft undergraduate students). Student services including the recruiting for admissions, counseling, a nationally recognized peer tutoring program, career development, financial aid admin., and student record administration. All of these services help to contribute to the sense of connectivity experienced by Muhlenberg Students while interacting in the campus community.

Activity3.Description: Auxiliary services: housing of 1,953 students; meals for approximately 1,750 students; and a Bookstore for approximately 2,193 students and 730 employees.

ActivityOther.Description: Operation and maintenance of physical plant: educational and administrative buildings agrounds (97 buildings). The beautiful 91 acre campus is highlighted by Gothic architecture and its signature historical buildings the Haas College Center, Baker Center for the Arts and Egner Memorial Chapel. Recent additions include the Trexler Pavilion for Theatre and Dance, a new science building, additions to hte Seegers Union building including a beautiful new campus restaurant, and eight spectacular new residence halls over the past decade.

Form990ScheduleDPartXIV.Explanation: The Martin Art Gallery provides the Muhlenberg and Lehigh Valley communities with significant opportunities for increased understanding of the visual arts, art history, and cultural diversity through the exhibition of works from the College's impressive permanent collection as well as through special exhibitions of work by contemporary artists, art faculty, or in collaboration with other art institutions. The Gallery's exhibition schedule is enhanced by gallery talks, artist receptions, and cross-curriculum programs. It occupies a prominent location on campus, in the Baker Center for the Arts, a striking arts facility designed by renowned American architect, Philip Johnson.

The College holds funds for the Women's Auxiliary of Muhlenberg College in the College's endowment investments. The College also holds agency funds on behalf of the Muhlenberg Student Government as well numerous Muhlenberg student clubs and organizations.
Endowment funds are used to support general operations, provide financial assistance to students, and support research opportunities for students and faculty.
Other liabilities includes accrued post retirement expenses, interest rate swap liability, unpaid claims liability and various withholdings /deposits to be paid to others.
Comprised of endowment gains used to meet spending policy and investment management expenses netted in the endowment income distribution.
Cost of goods sold which were netted.
Cost of goods sold and endowment gains used to meet spending policy.
Investment management fees netted in income distribution. Also includes expenses for Jewish Christian Institute that were netted with proceeds from endowment.

IRS990ScheduleE.PubViaBroadcastMediaExpln: NOTICE OF NONDISCRIMINATORY POLICY AS TO STUDENTS MUHLENBERG COLLEGE Muhlenberg College does not discriminate against any person based on age, color, disability, gender, gender identity, national or ethnic origin, race, religion, sexual orientation, veteran status, or any other basis protected by applicable federal, state or local laws. All inquiries regarding this policy and complaints of discrimination in violation of this policy may be directed to: Vice President of Human Resources Muhlenberg College Allentown, PA 18104 484-664-3165 Complaints will be handled in accordance with the appropriate procedures established for resolving such complaints as set forth in student, faculty and staff handbooks. In addition, inquiries concerning the application of Title IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 (prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex) may be directed to the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights, U. S. Department of Education.

Form990ScheduleJPartII.NamePerson: Michael S Bruckner VP of PR

Form990ScheduleJPartIII.Explanation: Housing is provided for the Provost, Dean of Students and the President of the College. The housing provided to the Dean of Students is considered a condition of employment. Only a portion of the President's housing is treated as taxable due ot the fact that a substantial portion of the residence is utilized for College events and activities. Travel is provided for the President's spouse only when she is considered to be conducting College business. Housekeeping services are provided for the President and it treated as a taxable benefit.

The process for determining the President's compensation is documented. Feedback from Trustees, Parent's Council and direct reports is compiled. This feedback, as well as the CIPA salary survey and data collected from the 990 returns of competitor institutions is reviewed by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees. The Committee then makes a recommendation to the full Board of Trustees for approval.

Senior staff of the College are eligible to participate in a Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan. Participation is permitted after approval by the Management Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section A, Line 2
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: Trustees Mark Paris and Tammy Bormann are husband and wife.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 11
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: A draft of the completed 990 form is posted to the Trustee web page maintained by the College. Trustees have the opportunity to review the return prior to a regularly scheduled meeting of the Trustees. The Audit and Compliance Committee of the Board of Trustees reviews the reutrn in detail. The Audit and Compliance Committee approves the return and reports its findings to the full Board of Trustees.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 12c
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: All faculty, staff, and Trustees must complete a Conflict of Interest Statement on an annual basis. Noted conflicts are reviewed by the Audit and Compliance Committee of the Board of Trustees. The College also utilizes controls to limit the stated conflicts when considering pertinent contracts or other potential College business.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section B, Line 15
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The annual compensation of the President is established by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Trustees, subject to approval by the Board. A wide array of feedback from stakeholders including Trustees, Parent's Council, and the President's direct reports is reviewed by the Committee. In addition, the Human Resources Office provides comparative data from the CUPA salary survey and collects compensation data , via 990 returns, from those institutions considered the top competitors of Muhlenberg College. The Committee also reviews the President's performance appraisals of all other College officers. The Committee receives and reviews comparative data from the CUPA Salary Survey and competitior institutions.

GeneralExplanation.ReturnReference: Form 990, Part VI, Section C, Line 19
GeneralExplanation.Explanation: The College's Conflict of Interest Policy is available to the public via the College website. College financial statements and governing documents are available upon request.
